Diparnmento dt lngegnena Chimica, Universith 'La Sapienza', Via Eudossiana 18, 00184 Rome, Italy Received 14 September 1995; revised 17 November 1995; accepted 17 November 1995 Abstract Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) has been used in this work to study the reduction of copper in CuO-ZnO catalysts with different Cu/Zn atomic ratios using H2 as reducing agent. In all catalysts, CuO was completely reduced to metal. The influence exerted by ZnO on the reduction of copper was evaluated for a wide range of composition and a scale of reducibility was established. ZnO affects the hydrogen reduction of copper, CuO-ZnO samples showing a different behaviour with respect to the pure copper oxide. The reduction is always promoted and, in particular, catalysts with lower copper loading (Cu:Zn < 30:70 as atomic ratio) showed the highest reactivity and are characterised by the presence of two reducible copper species. Results of a kinetic analysis based on the TPR profiles confirmed the role played by ZnO as promoter of the copper oxide reduction. The effect of the preparation method on the catalyst reducibility was also verified and discussed in a specific case. H2-CO2-H2 redox cycles were carried out on some representative samples which, after the first reduction in H2, were reoxidised with CO2 and then reduced again by H2. These experiments revealed that a small percent of metal copper formed in the CuO-ZnO catalysts is oxidised by CO2 regardless of the catalyst composition, whereas metal copper formed by reduction of pure CuO is not reoxidised at a detectable level. Furthermore, it was evidenced that the small fraction of copper reoxidised by CO2 was extremely reactive, being reduced at temperatures much lower than those found for the reduction of the as-prepared catalysts. Both the TPR investigation and the H2-CO2-H2 redox cycles clearly assessed the presence of a synergistic effect arising by the contact of CuO with the ZnO particles. Introduction Catalysts based on CuO-ZnO mixed oxides are of a considerable industrial interest owing to their activity for the low temperature-pressure methanol synthesis and the water-gas shift reaction. In consequence of its success, the CuO-ZnO system has prompted a great deal of fundamental work devoted to clarify either the role played by each component and the nature of the active sites. This is widely documented by several reviews [I-5] which bring also into evidence that controversial issues are yet lively. In fact if, on the one hand, there is a general agreement about the central role played by the reduced copper, on the other hand many questions remain still open. In particular, the interaction of copper with ZnO and the copper oxidation state supposed to be involved as active site during the catalytic process are object of extensive debate. Some authors state that a synergic effect arises by the contact with ZnO being the binary catalyst much more active than each component on its own [2,6,7]. In contrast to this, other authors claim that the active site is placed on a particle of copper metal and that no Cu-ZnO synergy occurs [8,9]. Bartley and Burch [10] and Denise et al. [11] have found pronounced support effects when different copper catalysts are tested for the methanol synthesis from both CO/H2 and CO2/H2 mixtures. In particular, Burch et al. have proposed that the role of ZnO is to act as a reservoir for hydrogen and to promote the hydrogen spill-over [12,13]. A detailed mechanism of the methanol synthesis, via hydrolysis of a zinc methoxide species, has been recently suggested by Fujita et al. [14]. If, on the one hand, some authors gave evidence that only metal copper and zinc oxide were present in the catalyst during the methanol synthesis [14-18], on the other hand, the formation of Cu+ has been also reported in literature [19-22]. In particular, Fujitani et al. suggested that the active component is not only Cu+ but also Cuand that the support may play the role to control the Cu+/Cu ratio on which the catalytic activity depends. The view, so far described, is further complicated by the fact that, depending on the experimental conditions and on the catalyst preparation history, the formation of a Cu-Zn alloy may also occur [23-25]. The presence of Cu+ species in the reduced Cu/ZnO and CuO/ZnO/AI203 catalysts has been reported in literature [3-6,26-30]. Results published until now by our group have given some evidence of the formation of monovalent copper upon reduction in hydrogen of Cu/ZnO catalysts and the role of ZnO has been also discussed [31-33]. By means of XPS, Moretti et al. found that a strong CuO-ZnO interaction exists in catalysts both at higher [33] and -at lower [34] copper content. Recently, by using X-ray diffraction and diffuse reflectance spectroscopy, Porta et al. have confirmed that a peculiar interaction occurred in the more diluted CuO-ZnO samples calcined at low temperatures [35]. In another recent work of our hand, dealing with a reduction kinetic study of some CuO-ZnO catalysts [36], a promoting effect of ZnO on the copper reducibility G. Fierro et al./ Applied Catalysis A: General 137 (1996) 327-348 329 has been reported. The present work is concerned with a TPR study of CuO-ZnO catalysts and with a kinetic analysis of their reduction process. Our aim is to evaluate the reactivity of copper, to gain a direct evidence of the Cu-ZnO synergism and to develop a kinetic model which is able to estimate the kinetic parameters of the reduction by a computer simulation of a single experimental TPR profile. Robertson et al. used the TPR technique first to study the reducibility in hydrogen of copper-nickel-on-silica catalysts and to evaluate the metal-support interaction [37]. Gentry et al. studied by TPR the promoting influence of transition metals on the reduction of CuO [38]. Fleisch and Mieville reported TPR profiles of pure CuO, CuO-ZnO and CuO-ZnO-A1203 catalysts and stated that the CuO reducibility is higher in the ternary than in the binary system being the CuO-ZnO-A1203 and the CuO-ZnO catalysts reduced at a temperature of 140 K lower and at 50 K higher with respect to pure CuO, respectively [29]. In a recent paper, Boyce et al. evaluated by TPR the reducibility of copper in CuO-ZnO catalysts whose composition ranged be- tween 3% up to 15% of CuO [39]. The TPR profiles of these catalysts showed single reduction peaks and the peak maxima, TM, were similar to those observed by the same authors for CuO alone [40]. Although copper-based catalysts have been investigated by TPR, the results obtained from the previous studies are sometimes contradictory and, in consequence, the role of the support towards the copper reduction cannot easily settled. On the other hand, it is not possible to compare the TPR results reported in literature because of the different catalyst preparation methods and different experimental conditions employed for the TPR runs. Therefore, we have carried out a systematic TPR study of the CuO-ZnO system in a wide range of Cu/Zn composition in order to assess the influence exerted by ZnO on the copper reducibility. Results of a kinetic analysis of the reduction process based on a computer simulation of the TPR profiles are also presented. Finally, in order to test the capability of CO2 to re-oxidise the reduced catalysts as well as to evaluate both the reactivity and the amount of the re-oxidised copper, H2-CO2-H2 redox cycles were carried out on some representative CuO-ZnO catalysts and on pure CuO. 2. Temperature-programmed reduction: apparatus and procedures The scheme of the TPR apparatus has been in detail described elsewhere [45]. It consists of two parts: (1) a flow system to perform the TPR measurements by applying a stream of diluted hydrogen and (2) a BET-type vacuum line where the sample pretreatment, trapping of the water released during the reduction and measurement of its quantity can be effected [45]. Ultrapure gases, H2 (99.999%), G. Fierro et al./Applied Catalysis A: General 137 (1996) 327-348 331 N2 (99.999%), 02 (99.995%) and He (99.995%), were employed with no further purification and a 4-channel electronic mass-flow controller (UCAR Instru- ments, Model MFB 30) was used for fixing the flow rates of each gas accurately. A temperature controller (Leeds and Northrup Instrument, Model Electromax V Plus) was used for the temperature programs. The HW detector and the temperature controller were connected to an IBM compatible personal computer and both the hydrogen uptake and the heating rate, /3, were digitally acquired and processed. No interference on the TPR profiles caused by mass transfer limitations or dispersion effects were observed under our experimental conditions [45,46]. Samples used for the TPR measurements have the consis- tency of a fine powder and particle sizes less than 100 /xm. A quartz-glass reactor with a porous septum was used. Depending on the catalyst composition, the reactor was loaded with a different quantity of catalyst (0.020-0.350 mg) in order to have a comparable amount of copper to be reduced. The experimental operating variables (i.e., the initial hydrogen concentration, co = 2.52 /xmol/ml, the initial amount of reducible species, So = 200-250 txmol and the total flow rate, V *= 40 ml/min) were carefully chosen in order to obtain optimum reduction profiles [45]. Before starting a TPR run, each sample was pretreated in-situ under flowing 02 at 573 K for 1 h, flushed with N2 at 573 K for 0.33 h and cooled in N2 to room temperature. A standard TPR run consisted of (i) an initial treatment in the reducing stream (40 ml/min of 6% v/v H2 in N2) at room temperature for 0.01 h, (ii) temperature programming, (iii) keeping the sample at the final temperature for 0.33 h and (iiii) outgassing of the sample at the final temperature for 0.33 h. The heating rate, /3, was fixed at 5 K min- unless stated otherwise. The total hydrogen consumption was determined in two ways: (a) by transmitting the HW detector output to an amplification and integration system (Shimadzu Instruments, Model Chromatopac C-R1B); (b) by estimating the water release during the reduction through a stepwise expansion into a calibrated zone of the vacuum line. Peaks in the TPR profiles were characterised by the temperature corresponding to the maximum hydrogen consumption rate, TM and the full width at half maximum, Wl/2. The repro- ducibility of both the peak shape and the peak maximum has been checked and it was always preserved. 2.3. H2-CO2-H2 redox cycles H2-CO2-H2 redox cycles were carried out on CuO obtained from malachite and on Cu:Zn = 85:15, 50:50 catalysts. In order to evaluate the influence of the preparation method on the catalyst reactivity, the 50:50-HN sample was also tested. A redox cycle consisted of three consecutive steps: (i) a standard TPR run (run A) of a fresh portion of the catalyst; (ii) an oxidation step by CO2 at 573 K for 0.33 h and (iii) a second TPR run (run B). The CO2, withdrawn at an initial partial pressure of about 70 Torr, was circulated over the catalyst through 332 G. He-COe-He redox cycles The H2-CO2-H2 redox cycles revealed that metal copper in the reduced CuO-ZnO catalysts can be partially re-oxidised by carbon dioxide regardless of the composition and preparation method. The copper re-oxidised by CO2 is much more easily reduced than the copper species initially present in the as-prepared catalysts. The large difference of TM values (about 100 K) between the fresh and the CO2-reoxidised specimens emphasises that the small fraction of copper re-oxidised by CO2 is extremely reactive (See also Fig. 4B). Since, ZnO is essential in order that the oxidation of copper by CO2 occurs to a detectable extent, at least in our experimental conditions, three hypotheses can be made: (i) CO2 is activated by ZnO, as suggested by Kinnaird et al. [51,52], (ii) copper dispersed and in intimate contact with ZnO is more reactive than isolated and massive copper oxides and (iii) both of these factors are coopera- tive. These proposed explanations may include and match the junction effect theory applied to the metal (Cu)-oxide-(ZnO) system. The initial dispersion of CuO and its interaction with ZnO is certainly an important factor influencing the reactivity of the reduced catalysts with CO2. In fact, depending on the dispersion of CuO, three different kinds of copper metal species have been reported for CuO-ZnO catalysts reduced in H2 [4]: (a) copper metal crystals, which resemble bulk Cu metal, (b) small copper metal clusters, described also as three-dimensional metal copper originated by CuO partially interacting with ZnO and, finally, (c) the so-called two-dimensional metal copper which is depicted as a thin layer epitaxially grown over the ZnO particles. In particular, the epitaxial metal copper is expected to be originated by copper species finely dispersed over the support and it was found to be preferentially oxidised when exposed to air [4]. However, it should not be much asked to consider the surface oxidation of copper or, at least, of that fraction of it located along the contact area with ZnO. According to this point of view, the preparation method and, consequently, the CuO-ZnO interaction, particle sizes, extension of contact area should assume an important role in the re-oxidation process. The influence of the preparation method on the dispersion of metal copper as well as on its reactivity with CO2 is indeed brought into evidence by a comparison between the Cu:Zn = 50:50-HN and 50:50 catalysts. The amount of copper reoxidised by CO2 in the Cu:Zn = 50:50-HN catalyst (37 /xmol/g), from the hydroxynitrate precursor, is much lower than that re-oxidised in the homologous 50:50 catalyst (215 /xmol/g) from the hydroxycarbonate precursor. This latter catalyst, in agreement with our TPR results, is characterised by a good interdispersion and a wide contact area between the CuO and ZnO particles [33], characteristics which were also found for the other CuO-ZnO specimens prepared by the same method [33-35]. Upon reduction of these catalysts, owing to the CuO-ZnO interaction and the rather high surface areas in the oxidised state (see Table 1), the sintering of metal copper is hampered so G. Moreover, metal copper dispersed and in intimate contact with ZnO can also give rise to metal-oxide junctions as proposed by Frost for small metal copper particles encapsulated by the oxide [53]. Conclusions The TPR investigation of CuO-ZnO catalysts prepared by coprecipitation at constant pH and thermal decomposition of hydroxycarbonate precursors showed that ZnO promotes the copper reducibility in the overall range of composition investigated by us. A single reduction process occurs for catalysts with higher Cu loading (Cu: 346 G. Fierro et al./Applied Catalysis A: General 137 (1996) 327-348 Zn = 92:8-30:70) whereas the lower copper content catalysts (Cu:Zn < 30:70) and in particular the Cu:Zn = 10:90 and 5:95 samples are characterised by two reduction processes related to the presence of two different copper species. One is similar to the CuO species present in the higher copper loading catalyst and is reduced alike, the other is represented by well dispersed copper in contact with the surface of ZnO particles which reduces at lower temperatures. This fraction of copper strongly interacting with ZnO increases on decreasing the copper content and showed the highest reducibility. The preparation method markedly influence the catalyst reduction and homo- geneity. The Cu:Zn = 50:50-HN catalyst (ex-hydroxynitrate precursor) is less reducible than the CuO:ZnO = 50:50 catalyst (ex-hydroxycarbonate precursor) and shows a dual Cu speciation not found in the latter specimen. The H2-CO2-H2 redox cycles revealed that reduced CuO-ZnO catalysts are partially re-oxidised by CO2 regardless of the composition, in contrast to reduced CuO which did not show a detectable re-oxidation. The small fraction of copper re-oxidised by CO2 is extremely reactive being reduced at a temperature about 100 K lower than that necessary to reduce the copper species in the as-prepared catalysts and the redox process is almost reversible. These results suggest, as a whole, that a CuCuox redox mechanism may occur at the boundary layers of metal copper in intimate contact with ZnO during the methanol synthesis, in particular from CO2-containing feeds. Accord- ingly, copper oxidised by COs rather than stabilised by support may be involved as the active site in the reaction mechanism. A kinetic model was developed which is able to evaluate the kinetic parame- ters (activation energy, reaction orders and the pre-exponential factor) of the reduction process from computer simulation of a single TPR profile. The kinetic analysis showed that the apparent activation energy, Ea, is 84 kJ/mol for the reduction of pure CuO whereas Ea decreased to 77 kJ/mol for the reduction of the CuO-ZnO catalysts, in agreement with the promoting effect played by ZnO on the reducibility of copper. The lowest value of Ea (61 kJ/mol) was found for the reduction of the CO2 re-oxidised CuO-ZnO catalysts. For both the as-pre- pared and the CO2 re-oxidised CuO-ZnO catalysts a linear relationship was observed between Ea and TM. Reaction orders close to 1 were found for copper and H2 and the pre-exponential factor was equal to 6.105 cm3//xmol s.
